metadata.title: Highly conductive and flexible nano-structured carbon-based polymer nanocomposites with improved electromagnetic-interference-shielding performance

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Thanks to their excellent qualities such as light weight, low cost, easy processability, corrosion resistance, and versatility, conductive polymer composites are pioneering materials for use in enclosures for electrical and electronics instruments for protection from electromagnetic (EM) waves and also fulfill electromagnetic interference (EMI)-shielding requirements [1–3]. Thus, a good EMI-shield material should suppress both incoming and outgoing EM waves, while not interfering with other electronic/electrical devices or itself [4, 5]. Owing to the massive usage of electronic or electrical gadgets and communication devices, EMI of EM waves emitted from these devices become a recurring problem in everyday civilian life [6–8].
Traditionally, metal or metal-based composites are the primary choice for EMI shields, but these materials often face problems with high weight, low flexibility, corrosion, tough processability, and chemical resistance [4]. These severe difficulties can be overcome with the use of most common eco-friendly conductive polymer composites containing carbonaceous materials, which open the door for the development of promising EMI shields. The conductive polymer composites have several unique advantages such as low cost, easy processability, corrosion resistance, and being easy to handle [9]. Carbonaceous materials such as carbon nanotube (CNT) [10], graphene [11], graphene nanoplatelets [12], carbon fiber [13], carbon nanofiber (CNF) [14], and carbon black [15] have attracted great interest due to their excellent properties, including good mechanical properties, thermal durability, electrical conductivity, and adjustable EMI-shielding behavior. CNF, especially, is considered to be an excellent alternative material for EMI shielding, as it has excellent electrical properties, a high aspect ratio, good mechanical properties, high corrosion resistance, low density and shows a strong interaction with

CNF nanofiller is most commercially available in bulk quantity, comparably cost-effective, and shows good thermal and chemical stability in comparison to CNT nanofiller [14]. Designing an economically and technically sound conductive polymer composite with CNF nanofiller to meet superior EMI-shielding requirements is crucial due to composite processing cost, agglomeration tendency, and processing complexity. Several articles have already been published on the EMI shielding of CNF/polymer composites [10, 16–19]. Most of the researchers have not paid attention to material cost, processing obstacles such as homogeneous dispersion and agglomeration tendency, which is the most important criterion for commercial shield materials. To address this important criterion, CNF/CPE (chlorinated polyethylene) nanocomposites have been fabricated by a probesonication-assisted solution-mixing process to figure out the above-mentioned problems. The solution-mixing process provides well-dispersed nanofiller inside the polymer matrix with sonic-wave treatment compared to a viable-melt mixing procedure. Our target was to prepare such a composite without any phase separation of nanofiller inside the host matrix with greater homogeneity. However, the better dispersion of nanofillers can be achieved by probe-sonication treatment with the solution-mixing approach. In the present study, CPE and CNF are used as the host matrix and the conductive nanofiller, respectively. CPE is a unique class of polymer which has considerable versatility in relation to being an adhesion promoter, compatibilization agent, having low-temperature toughness, as well as excellent resistance to UV radiation, hydrocarbon oil, chemical, flame, and weather, respectively [20, 21]. Hence, the implication of this choice of polymer (CPE) is very significant here. We choose it not only as a simple polymer matrix, but also as a stabilizing agent, and adhesion promoter for CNFs. In terms of electrical conductivity, the filler content is crucial to achieve the lower percolation concentration. Among the carbonaceous nanofillers, CNFs are already proven to be the most significant, showing relatively low percolation behavior with high surface area and length. However, CNFs are the most superior carbonaceous filler to be used as a conductivity- and EMI-shielding efficiency (EMI-SE) enhancer for polymer composites. Herein, we present a probe-sonication-assisted solution-mixing process for fabricating CPE/CNF nanocomposites containing various loading of CNF nanofiller, which demonstrate enhanced shielding performance in the X-band along with other desired properties. The present work systematically investigates the effect of the sequential alteration of CNF nanofiller on properties such as the thermal durability, electrical conductivity, and EMI-shielding performance of CPE nanocomposites. The pivotal importance of the adopted processing technique, nanofiller, and polymer matrix combination has been highlighted to establish their practical utility and commercial viability.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: CPE polymer with 36% chlorine content was obtained from Eastcorp International, India. CNF nanofiller (PR-24-XT-PS) with diameter 100 nm and surface area 45 m2 g−1 was purchased from Pyrograf Products Inc., Ohio. Tetrahydrofuran (THF) solvent was purchased from Merck Specialities Private Limited, India. Dibutyltin dilaurate (DBTDL) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich for use as a heat stabilizer and magnesium oxide from Loba Chemie for use as an acid scavenger. Triallyl cyanurate (TAC) was procured from Fluka Chemie Ag, Germany for use as a coagent and dicumyl peroxide (DCP) from Hercules, India for use as a curing agent.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of CPE/CNF nanocomposites
sections.text:
CPE and CNFs were first dried in a drying oven at 70 °C for 20 h to remove the adsorbed moisture. CNFs were then dispersed in the THF by probe-sonication for 30 min at room temperature. The calculated amount of CPE, MgO, and DBTDL were magnetically stirred in THF for 20 min to allow them to dissolve. Then, the dispersed CNF solution was added dropwise to the polymer solution under continuous magnetic stirring for 1 h and then sonicated via probe sonication for 20 min, which shows each CPE/CNF solution of varying CNF content to ensure better dispersion of the CNF nanofiller. Following this, TAC (co-agent) and DCP (curing agent) were added to the CPE/CNF suspension under continuous stirring for 10 min. The prepared suspension was cast on a glass petri dish and kept at the normal temperature for 36 h and then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 5 h to remove entrapped solvent residues. Finally, the dried samples were molded at 165 °C under 5 MPa pressure for an optimum cure time (measured with a Monsanto oscillating disc rheometer, ODR, 100S) of 10 min using a hydraulic press (George E. Moore & Son (Birmingham) Ltd, UK). The details of the preparation method are described in figure 1 and the formulations of CPE/CNF nanocomposites are given in table 1. The CPE nanocomposites are designated as ‘CPF-X’, where ‘CP’ stands for CPE polymer, ‘F’ stands for CNF nanofiller, and ‘X’ represents the weight% of the CNF nanofiller. Mater. Res. sections.heading: 2.3. Material characterization
sections.text: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis was evaluated using an FTIR spectrometer (Perkin Elmer Lambda 35, Singapore) in attenuated total reflection mode in the region of 4000–500 cm−1 with a spectral resolution of 0.5 cm−1. The microstructure of samples was investigated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM; Zeiss EVO-60, Carl ZEISS SMT, Germany; operating at 5 kV) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM; JEOL-JEM 2100, Japan; operating at 200 kV). For SEM analysis, thin gold-coated cryofractured samples were used. TEM specimens were prepared by ultramicrotomy (Leica UltraCut EM FCS Ultracryotom) with cryosections of 300 nm thickness under −60 °C. Thermal durability was investigated using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA Q5000, TA Instruments, USA) at a heating rate of 20 °C min−1 in an inert environment (nitrogen) over a temperature range of 40–700 °C. The room temperature DC resistance was measured by an Agilent 4339B and Agilent 34401A 6 1/2 digit multimeter with a circular copper electrode (area = 1.327 cm2). The conductivity values were the average value of three different specimens with standard deviation <3. The EMI SE performance of CPE nanocomposites was performed using an E5071C VNA series vector network analyzer (Agilent Technologies) in the X-band frequency range from 8.2–12.4 GHz.

sections.heading: 3.1. FTIR analysis of CPE nanocomposites
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of the neat CPE matrix and its nanocomposites are shown in figure 2. From FTIR spectrum, several absorption bands observed at about 2910, 2848, 1455, 1270, 889, 807, and 667 cm−1. The characteristic absorption bands are observed at 2910 and 2849 cm−1 due to methylene stretching where 1455 and 807 cm−1 peaks demonstrate the methylene bending and –CHCl– bending vibrations, respectively [22]. The rocking mode

sections.heading: 3.2. Dispersion or distribution of CNFs in the CPE matrix
sections.text: Figure 3 shows the dispersion and adhesion of CNF with CPE chains schematically. The CNF bundles are disintegrated into approximately independent nanofiber under probe-sonication treatment, which improves the proper dispersion in THF solvent. CNF-nanofiller suspension is added dropwise to the CPE/THF solution, and the CPE molecular chains are strongly adsorbed on the surfaces of the CNF nanofiller. The efficient and effective dispersion of nanofiller in the polymer matrix is responsible for enhanced properties as well as the final performance of the composites. Therefore, the morphological investigation (dispersion or distribution) of CPE/CNF nanocomposites was examined by SEM and HRTEM analysis.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. SEM analysis of CPE nanocomposites
sections.text: The cryo-fractured SEM micrographs display the surface morphology (dispersion, distribution, and their physical interaction with the polymer matrix) of CPE/CNF nanocomposites containing 5, 15, and 25 wt% CNF loading, as shown in figures 4(a)–(c). From SEM micrographs, it is clearly seen that the thread-like structure of the CNF nanofiller is well decorated and excellently embedded in the CPE polymer matrix. Additionally, much less CNFs were pulled from the CPE matrix. It is worth noting that the CNFs exhibit a layer-type morphology in the polymer matrix, which may be formed when sequential solvent evaporation from CPE/CNF solution at room temperature occurs. Some microscopic porosity and voids were observed on the cryo-fractured surface at higher nanofiller loading. The surface roughness of CPE nanocomposites increases with the nanofiller loading [20]. As expected, more physical connections and continuous conductive networks of CNF nanofillers can be observed due to a decrease in the average distance between CNFs in the CPE matrix with increasing CNF content. This roughness and physical connections can increase electrical conductivity through more contact points and, consequently, improve the mechanical interlocking and interfacial adhesion between CNFs and CPE chains [20]. Thus, the compactness of CNF conductive frameworks is increasing with increasing CNF nanofiller [24]. This efficient and effective dispersion or distribution of CNF nanofiller within the CPE matrix has a significant role in enhanced electrical conductivity and EMI-shielding performance as well as the desired properties of the nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. HRTEM analysis of CPE nanocomposites
sections.text:
The bulk dispersion and distribution of CNF nanofiller inside the CPE matrix is observed by HRTEM micrographs (figures 5(a)–(d)). From these, the hollow portion of CNF nanofillers was clearly observed. The CNF nanofillers are mostly isolated from each other at the filler loading of 2 wt%, whereas conductive CNFs are very much close to each other to form a continuous conductive network structure at higher loading. This observation suggests that the percolation threshold must be less than 5 wt% CNF-nanofiller content. The good
Figure 2. FTIR spectrum of neat CPE and CPE/CNF nanocomposites.
Mater. Res. Express 4 (2017) 105039

dispersion, random orientation, and less agglomeration of CNF nanofiller in the CPE matrix up to 15 wt% CNF loading can be seen clearly. The close-packed network structure, proper interaction, and excellent entrapment of CNF nanofiller inside the CPE matrix may be responsible for superior electrical conductivity and EMI-SE [20, 24]. However, the good decoration of CNF nanofiller inside the CPE matrix is essential for fabricating the flexible, lightweight polymer composites with a promising electrical property and EMI-suppressing ability in relation to EM radiation.

sections.heading: 3.3. Flexibility study
sections.text: Flexible composite materials have various advantages in their field application when materials are subjected to practical use. The CPE/CNF nanocomposites (here CPF-25) show excellent flexibility and foldability without any damage when bent, twisted, and even rolled up as shown in digital photographs (figures 6(a) and (b)).

sections.heading: 3.4. Thermal durability analysis of pure CPE and CPE/CNF nanocomposites
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is a one of the most significant techniques for understanding the thermal tolerance of materials and evaluation of its service life on exposure to a harsh thermal environment. TGA and DTG (differential thermogravimetric analysis) of CPE/CNF nanocomposites are shown in figures 7(a) and (b). The effect of nanofiller loading on the thermal durability of the CPE matrix was investigated as a function of temperature ranging from 45–700 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. From figure 7, it can be seen that there is a two-step degradation onset. First, degradation is responsible for HCl evolution from the CPE-chain backbone in the temperature range of 260–380 °C where the second degradation indicates the CH2–CH2 bond scission and evolution of hydrocarbons from CPE chains in the temperature range of 450–510 °C [14]. To determine the nature of the structural degradation of the composite, we obtained FTIR spectra of residues that were collected during TGA analysis after 400 °C and 700 °C. Figure 8 shows the spectra of CPF-25 residue after TGA analysis. At 400 °C, the characteristic C–Cl stretching bands (600–690 cm−1) are absent. These were present in the spectrum of CPE composites before TGA analysis. This is due to practically all of the chlorine groups having been removed from the polymer backbone as evolution of HCl without any appreciable breakdown of the polymer backbone chains occurs. Increasing the temperature to 700 °C, FTIR spectra of residue gives a flat spectrum that is completely different from the spectrum of CPE composites, indicating bond scission of the alkyl moiety and degradation of the CH2–CH2 bond. From the analysis, it is worth noting that the thermal durability was enhanced with the addition of CNF nanofiller. The residue was increased with nanofiller loading at 700 °C. The first-onset mass loss starts at 296 °C for the neat CPE matrix, and 303, 309, 314, 319, 322, and 325 °C for 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 wt% CNF-nanofiller-loaded nanocomposites, respectively. The second-onset mass loss begins at 482 °C for the neat CPE matrix, and 484, 487, 493, 495, 498, and 510 °C for 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 wt% CNF-nanofiller-loaded nanocomposites, respectively. This enhanced thermal durability depends on the dispersion and also on the interfacial interaction of CNF nanofiller with the CPE matrix. From TGA analysis, thermal durability of all nanocomposites ranges up to 460 °C, which indicates the good serviceability of nanocomposites on harsh thermal exposure.

sections.heading: 3.5. DC electrical conductivity of pure CPE and CPE/CNF nanocomposites
sections.text:
The effect of CNF-nanofiller concentration on the electrical conductivity of CPE/CNF nanocomposites is shown in figure 9. The neat CPE matrix exhibits DC conductivity (σDC) of >10−15 S cm−1. As expected, the σDC of CPE nanocomposites increases with the addition of CNF-nanofiller loading where the electrical conductivity shows the 5.9 × 10−12, 2.2 × 10−8, 5 × 10−5, 7 × 10−3, 8.3 × 10−2, and 1.4 × 10−1 S cm−1 values for a loading of 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 wt% of CNF nanofiller, respectively. However, the enhanced electrical conductivity demonstrates the good dispersion of nanofiller inside the polymer matrix and increase in continuous conductive
Figure 6. Digital photographs of (a) bent and (b) rolled CPE/CNF nanocomposite (CPF-25).
Figure 7. (a) TGA, and (b) DTG thermograms of neat CPE and its nanocomposites.
Mater. Res. Express 4 (2017) 105039
8
S Mondal et al
networks with gradual increment in nanofiller content [7, 10, 20]. At lower nanofiber loading, electrons have to either hop or tunnel through the thin layers of polymer due to there being more gaps between nanofibers. From the figure, we found that the conductivity increases by eight orders of magnitude upon increasing the CNF content from 0 to 5 wt%, indicating the percolation threshold. After the percolation threshold, the formation of multiple continuous conducting paths becomes saturated. The percolation threshold is defined as a sharp increase in electrical conductivity with critical conductive filler concentration through the formation of continuous conductive networks [3]. The percolation threshold of nanocomposites can be calculated from classical power-law theory: σDC = k(wt%–wtc%)t, where σDC is electrical conductivity of the composite, k is a constant, wt% is the weight percent of the CNF nanofiller and wtc% represents the critical-weight percent of CNF nanofiller, and t represents the critical exponent. The plot of logσDC versus log(wt%–wtc%) is shown in the inset of figure 9 and displays the best-fit data on the basis of classical theory. The percolation threshold is found at 2.87 wt%. Therefore, the low percolation-threshold value is the result of the improved dispersion of CNF nanofiller inside the CPE matrix through the adopted mixing process.

sections.heading: 3.6. Electromagnetic-interference-shielding efficiency of pure CPE and CPE/CNF nanocomposites
sections.text:
Good decoration and proper dispersion of nanofillers as well as the formation of continuous conductive networks inside the insulating polymer matrix have established the development of promising EMI-shield materials [4, 10]. The EMI-SE can be defined as the logarithm ratio of the incident-to-transmitted EM wave within the material and is calculated as [4, 17, 25] SE = 10log (Pin/Pout) (1) where Pin and Pout are incident and transmitted power of the EM radiation, respectively. However, the total shielding effectiveness in relation to decibels (dB) is measured from scattering parameters using the following equations:
Figure 8. FTIR spectrum of CPF-25 residue after 400 °C and 700 °C.
Mater. Res. Express 4 (2017) 105039
9
S Mondal et al
SER = 10log (1 − R) (2) SEA = 10log [T/ (1 − R)] (3) SEtotal = SER + SEA + SEM (neglectedat > 10 dB) . Here SER, SEA, and SEM represent the shielding by reflection, absorption, and multiple reflections, respectively. Shielding effectiveness by reflection is one of the primary attenuation mechanisms that can occur due to the impedance mismatch between the air and material front facet when frequency varies. Additionally, high conductivity is the primary concern, whereas absorption mainly leads to subsequent energy dissipation between the EM wave and the shield [20, 26, 27]. The multiple reflections mainly arise as a result of the scattering effect of inhomogeneity within the shield material. The multiple reflections can be neglected when the SE is greater than 10 dB and the thickness of the material is also higher than the material skin depth [28]. In addition, polarization loss, ohmic loss, and material thickness are the main concerns in relation to high absorption where reflection from

material surfaces and interfaces increases with increasing intrinsic electrical conductivity through tunneling, hopping, and conduction mechanisms [4, 29]. The schematic representation of the EMI-shielding mechanism of CPE/CNF nanocomposites is shown in figures 10(a) and (b).
To further confirm the reliability of the dispersion of CNFs inside the CPE matrix and optimization of EMIshielding performance, we measured the EMI SE efficiency of CPE/CNF nanocomposites with a 1 mm thickness at the X-band frequency range (8.2–12.4 GHz). Figure 11(a) shows the EMI SE values of the CPE nanocomposites gradually increases with the incorporation of CNF nanofiller, which is attributed mainly to the higher conductivity through the formation of continuous conductive network. The EMI SE shows the weak dependence on the frequency in the measured frequency range. The average EMI SE of the neat CPE matrix shows very weak ability against EM radiation. Nanocomposites containing 2 wt% CNF exhibit an EMI SE value of 8.4 dB, which is close to blocking 90% of the EM radiation. For 10 wt%, the CNF composite reached an EMI SE value of 23.9 dB, which fulfills the primary criteria of techno-commercial EM radiation-blocking applications and also blocked >99.9% EM radiation. It is noted that the EMI SE values increase from 8.4–41.5 dB at 2 to 25 wt% CNF loading at a critical thickness of 1 mm.
Figure 11(b) further elaborates on the EMI-SE via shielding by absorption (SEA), shielding by reflection (SER), and total shielding effectiveness (SEtotal). The SEA value of CPE/CNF nanocomposites exhibit 6.84, 13.66, 20.02, 24.51, 30.59, and 35.65 dB and also an SER value of 1.56, 2.72, 3.87, 4.68, 5.14, and 5.85 dB with 2, 5, 10,
Mater. Res. Express 4 (2017) 105039
11
S Mondal et al
15, 20, and 25 wt% CNF content, respectively. It is noted that both SER and SEA increases with CNF-nanofiller loading, where SEA increases with a much faster rate as compared to SER. Here, improvement of total EMI SE is attributed to the greater dominance of SEA compared to the SER mechanism. These findings indicate that most of the incident EM radiation is difficult to escape for CPE nanocomposites due to the fact it is mostly absorbed and dissipates rather than reflecting EM radiation.
The skin depth of shield material is defined as the EM radiation strength decreasing exponentially as it travels through the material and a certain distance, up to which the intensity of electric field drops to 1/e of its original value. Theoretically, it can be expressed by δ = (2/fμσ)1/2 = −8.68(t/SEA) [4, 30], where ƒ is the measured frequency, t is the thickness of the nanocomposite material and μ and σ are the permeability and conductivity of the nanocomposite material, respectively. Determination of skin depth from scattering parameters shows an inverse proportionality with the absorption of the shield material. Typically, the multiple reflections reduce the overall SE when the thickness of material is less than the skin depth. This type of reflection can be ignored if the thickness of the shield material is higher than the skin depth, as the reflected EM radiation from internal surface will be absorbed by the conductive shield material [30]. Figure 12 demonstrates that the skin depth of CPE/CNF nanocomposites decreased from 1.26 mm for CPF-2 to 0.24 mm for CPF-25, which describes the desired level of attenuation with higher nanofiller loading at a critical thickness. It is obvious that the skin depth depends on the dispersion and loading of nanofiller as well as interconnected conducting mesh. The skin depth of CPE nanocomposites decreases with the addition of conductive nanofiller in the CPE matrix. Incorporation of CNF not only reduces the interconnected conductive mesh, but also the skin depth of the shield material [30].
EMI SE also depends on the thickness of the material. EM attenuation has a direct correlation with thickness variation. Generally, attenuation of the EM wave is improved by increasing shield thickness, which is governed

For example, the EMI efficiency of CPF-25 for different variations of thickness is shown in figures 13(a) and (b). The shielding-efficiency values gradually increase with a faster rate when the thickness is increased from 0.5 mm to 2.0 mm. The EMI-SE of CPF-25 is 33.2 dB for a shield thickness of 0.5 mm and achieved 47.45 dB with a 2.0 mm thickness.
Generally, the improved EMI-SE of CPE/CNF nanocomposites depends on various factors [31]: (i) high electric conductivity through the formation of a continuous conductive network, (ii) free movement of a greater number of mobile charge carriers, (iii) formation of conductive mesh that decreases with increasing CNF-nanofiller loading, (iv) interaction of a greater number of conducting and absorbing sites with increasing nanofiller content, (v) proper dispersion and distribution of nanofiller inside the CPE matrix, (vi) efficient electron transport and (vii) higher absorption dependent on dielectric properties including conduction loss, dipolar relaxation, thickness, and electrical polarization where intensified polarization was derived from functional groups, defects, and available interfaces [4, 31–33].
The conductive polymer composite materials and their derivatives vary with thickness, mixing procedure, and EMI-SE (as reported in the existing literature). The EMI-shielding performance of various conductive composites with different thickness, conductive-filler loading, and mixing process (as a contrast to the present work) is listed in table 3. From table 3, it is clearly evident that the SE obtained in the present study is quite high in com-
parison to the previously reported studies available in the EMI-shielding field.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: The present study addresses the highly flexible, lightweight, and affordable EMI-shield material fabricated by probe-sonication-assisted solution-mixing method using CPE polymer with sequential alteration of CNF nanofiller. Morphological analysis reveals the proper dispersion and distribution throughout the CPE matrix by both the actions of sonication and strong interfacial interaction. The as-prepared nanocomposites not only facilitate good thermal durability and electrical conductivity, but also provide strong EM-radiation absorption ability, which was mainly attributed to the good dispersion of CNF nanofillers. These CPE nanocomposites show a superior EMI-SE of 41.5 dB with a low percolation-threshold value of 2.87 wt%. The composite material (CPF25) also displays a superior EMI efficiency of 47.5 dB for a 2.0 mm thickness at 8.2 GHz. The superior EMIshielding performance of the CPE nanocomposites containing CNF nanofiller proves it as an emerging shield material for protection against EM radiation over the X-band frequency range, which may used in future EMIshielding applications.

Generally, the improved EMI-SE of CPE/CNF nanocomposites depends on various factors [31]: (i) high electric conductivity through the formation of a continuous conductive network, (ii) free movement of a greater number of mobile charge carriers, (iii) formation of conductive mesh that decreases with increasing CNF-nanofiller loading, (iv) interaction of a greater number of conducting and absorbing sites with increasing nanofiller content, (v) proper dispersion and distribution of nanofiller inside the CPE matrix, (vi) efficient electron transport and (vii) higher absorption dependent on dielectric properties including conduction loss, dipolar relaxation, thickness, and electrical polarization where intensified polarization was derived from functional groups, defects, and available interfaces [4, 31–33].

metadata.abstractText: Widespread usage and development of electrical/electronic devices can create severe problems for various other devices and in our everyday lives due to harmful exposure to electromagnetic (EM) radiation. Herein, we report on the electromagnetic interference (EMI)-shielding performance of highly flexible and conductive chlorinated polyethylene (CPE)/carbon nanofiber (CNF) nanocomposites fabricated by a probe-sonication-assisted simple solution-mixing process. The dispersion of CNF nanofillers inside the CPE matrix has been studied by electron micrographs. This dispersion is reflected in the formation of continuous conductive networks at a low percolationthreshold value of 2.87 wt% and promising EMI-shielding performance of 41.5 dB for 25 wt% CNF in the X-band frequency (8.2–12.4 GHz). Such an intriguing performance mainly depends on the unique filler–filler or filler–polymer networks in CPE nanocomposites. In addition, the composite material displays a superior EMI efficiency of 47.5 dB for 2.0 mm thickness at 8.2 GHz. However, we have been encouraged by the promotion of highly flexible and lightweight CPE/CNF nanocomposite as a superior EMI shield, which can protect electronic devices against harm caused by EM radiation and offers an adaptable solution in advanced EMI-shield applications.
